Washington College To Face
Black And Blue Team
At Homewood

To Afford A Staunch
Battle
Johns Hopkins will be served its
first taste of football tomorrow
when the eleven inaugurates its 1933
campaign 'at Homewood Field
against Washington College.
The Eastern Shoremen, with a
squad composed of eighteen veterans in addition to the freshmen,
promise to offer a staunch battle.
Dick Gamber, captain of Washington's team, will hold down one of
the end positions again, while Spider
Skipp, the man mountain of last
year's basketball team, takes care of
the other.
Veteran Line

At the tackles are Ward and
Lord. The latter exhibited versatility last season when he performed
at guard and at center as well, in
emergency instances. Harries, the
regular center, is back again this
year, and Carey, Nowak and Tignor, all veterans, will share the
guard duties.
'Bilancioni, Reinhold, Beery and
Griems compose the backfield.
Griems is the only freshman in the
line-up. Reinhold will do most of
the Maroon punting, while Griems
and Bilancioni are touted as ball
carriers.
Jay Lineup Uncertain

At present, the starting Hopkins
line-up is undecided. However,
Ives, Van Orman, Phillips, Captain Russell, Giardina and Yearley
are sure to see service on the Black
and Blue forward wall.
Due to the many withdrawals
from the university because of financial difficulties, the Blue Jay reserve list has been weakened considerably.

When the blue squad trots out on the field tomorrow it will be to face another season just as mediocre, in spite of all press reports to the contrary, as
have been the past six or eight seasons. No expert
diagnostician is required in order to arrive at that
conclusion—it's self-evident from the material available and the schools to be met. Even if every game
were to be won, which is quite improbable, there would
still be no very significant accomplishment in the
sporting world.
Football at the Hopkins is in a very deplorable
state. For some reason there is a consistent dearth
of crackerjack material, most of the men being light
in weight and not coming out in sufficient numbers to
form an adequate reserve strength. With the situation such it is no wonder that we cannot schedule
any better than second or third rate teams without
being annihilated and with the University's present
lack of funds there is no prospect of our being able
to induce better athletes by means of athletic scholarships.
These factors would seem to spell all sorts of
doom for any team, yet the, surprising fact remains
that the football season pays for the deficits of the
basketball, track, and lacrosse squads. Even though
the Hopkins lacrosse squad is the recognized world
champion of the sport there are more outsiders willing
to pay to see the Hampden-Sydney gridders bow to
us in defeat by a small margin than to see us trample
the crack U. of M. stickmen.
Even this redeeming feature does not relieve the
student body from the blame due it for its steady
lack of team support year after year. There are many
explanations offered for the apathy of the undergraduates with regards to sports, but in the final analysis
the disinterest is directly attributable to sophistication—you know, the sort that makes an upperclassman afraid that a freshman will see him cheering.

Once more the perspiring efforts of "Red"
Schaal have evolved into a list of invited speakers
for the Supper Club; once more his scurrying henchmen are poking membership cards at us; and once
more we turn them away with a deaf ear and an
cmpty pocketbook. Whatta system!
In spite of our impervious attitude we have to
concede the Supper Club boys are really a live spot
on the campus, to be classed along with the Liberal
Club and Broadus Mitchell in their eternal quest for
the ideal. The disconcerting thing is, though, that
the Club always does seem to have ideal speakers, men
with something to say and an interesting way of
putting it. Wise, Niebuhr, Page, and Miller, on this
year's list, are particularly so gifted.
Although "Red" has lapsed somewhat into the
category of a campus fixture in the minds of most of
us, he is still contributing definitely to the opportunities which make the college man's life profitable. We
don't have a single Club subscription for sale, so we
can say honestly the man who attends the meetings
will come off bettered in outlook and information.

Rhodes Applications
Due November 11
November 11 has been designated
as the last day upon which applications for the Rhodes Scholarships for 1934-35 will be received,
it was announced by Dean Edward
W. Berry.
The scholarships, which are tenable at the University of Oxford,
are made for two years with an annual stipend of 400 pounds sterling.
The qualities which will be considered in making a choice of scholars are: (1) Literary and scholastic
ability and attainments, (2) qualities of manhood, truth, courage, devotion to duty, sympathy, kindliness,
unselfishness and fellowship; (3)
exhibition of moral force of character and of instincts to lead and
to take an interest in his schoolmates; and (4) physical vigor as
shown by interest in outdoor sports
or in other ways.
The Hopkins men chosen will apPear with other applicants from
Maryland and the District of Columbia before the State Committee,
Which will nominate frpm the candidates applying to it the two best
men to appear before the District
Committee. The forty-eight states
have been divided into eight districts
of six states each. Each district
committee will select from the
twelve state-approved applicants,
four men to represent their states as
Rhode's Scholars at Oxford.
Further information and application blanks may be obtained from
Dean Berry.

Fifty white rats are subjects in a
psychology experiment which will
be conducted over a period of one
year under the direction of Dr. Roy
M. Dorcus, associate in psychology
of the Johns Hopkins University.
The experiments, which are being carried on in a temporary building behind Homewood Field, are
designed to ascertain if rats, given
the choice of foods both good and
bad for their physical well-being
will choose the food most beneficial
for them.
To make the selection more difficult, between the "staging box"
and the "feeding box" a maze is

IN

placed, so that the longest and mos'
difficult route is that leading to th(
best food, while food not so wel
suited for a rat's diet may be mosi
easily reached. Thus, the test wil
disclose also valuable informatior
as to the degrees of intelligence. T
C. E. Wilder, assistant to Dr. I ir
II
Dorcus, who is actually making the
tests and observations, explains that
since the tests have been under way
for so short a period conclusive re- SC(
sults have not been obtained, but
that it is believed much valuable information will be forthcoming over m
ac
the long period in which the studies
are being made.

Washington College To Face
Black And Blue Team
At Homewood

To Afford A Staunch
Battle
Johns Hopkins will be served its
first taste of football tomorrow
when the eleven inaugurates its 1933
campaign 'at Homewood Field
against Washington College.
The Eastern Shoremen, with a
squad composed of eighteen veterans in addition to the freshmen,
promise to offer a staunch battle.
Dick Gamber, captain of Washington's team, will hold down one of
the end positions again, while Spider
Skipp, the man mountain of last
year's basketball team, takes care of
the other.
Veteran Line

At the tackles are Ward and
Lord. The latter exhibited versatility last season when he performed
at guard and at center as well, in
emergency instances. Harries, the
regular center, is back again this
year, and Carey, Nowak and Tignor, all veterans, will share the
guard duties.
'Bilancioni, Reinhold, Beery and
Griems compose the backfield.
Griems is the only freshman in the
line-up. Reinhold will do most of
the Maroon punting, while Griems
and Bilancioni are touted as ball
carriers.
Jay Lineup Uncertain

At present, the starting Hopkins
line-up is undecided. However,
Ives, Van Orman, Phillips, Captain Russell, Giardina and Yearley
are sure to see service on the Black
and Blue forward wall.
Due to the many withdrawals
from the university because of financial difficulties, the Blue Jay reserve list has been weakened considerably.

When the blue squad trots out on the field tomorrow it will be to face another season just as mediocre, in spite of all press reports to the contrary, as
have been the past six or eight seasons. No expert
diagnostician is required in order to arrive at that
conclusion—it's self-evident from the material available and the schools to be met. Even if every game
were to be won, which is quite improbable, there would
still be no very significant accomplishment in the
sporting world.
Football at the Hopkins is in a very deplorable
state. For some reason there is a consistent dearth
of crackerjack material, most of the men being light
in weight and not coming out in sufficient numbers to
form an adequate reserve strength. With the situation such it is no wonder that we cannot schedule
any better than second or third rate teams without
being annihilated and with the University's present
lack of funds there is no prospect of our being able
to induce better athletes by means of athletic scholarships.
These factors would seem to spell all sorts of
doom for any team, yet the, surprising fact remains
that the football season pays for the deficits of the
basketball, track, and lacrosse squads. Even though
the Hopkins lacrosse squad is the recognized world
champion of the sport there are more outsiders willing
to pay to see the Hampden-Sydney gridders bow to
us in defeat by a small margin than to see us trample
the crack U. of M. stickmen.
Even this redeeming feature does not relieve the
student body from the blame due it for its steady
lack of team support year after year. There are many
explanations offered for the apathy of the undergraduates with regards to sports, but in the final analysis
the disinterest is directly attributable to sophistication—you know, the sort that makes an upperclassman afraid that a freshman will see him cheering.

Once more the perspiring efforts of "Red"
Schaal have evolved into a list of invited speakers
for the Supper Club; once more his scurrying henchmen are poking membership cards at us; and once
more we turn them away with a deaf ear and an
cmpty pocketbook. Whatta system!
In spite of our impervious attitude we have to
concede the Supper Club boys are really a live spot
on the campus, to be classed along with the Liberal
Club and Broadus Mitchell in their eternal quest for
the ideal. The disconcerting thing is, though, that
the Club always does seem to have ideal speakers, men
with something to say and an interesting way of
putting it. Wise, Niebuhr, Page, and Miller, on this
year's list, are particularly so gifted.
Although "Red" has lapsed somewhat into the
category of a campus fixture in the minds of most of
us, he is still contributing definitely to the opportunities which make the college man's life profitable. We
don't have a single Club subscription for sale, so we
can say honestly the man who attends the meetings
will come off bettered in outlook and information.

Rhodes Applications
Due November 11
November 11 has been designated
as the last day upon which applications for the Rhodes Scholarships for 1934-35 will be received,
it was announced by Dean Edward
W. Berry.
The scholarships, which are tenable at the University of Oxford,
are made for two years with an annual stipend of 400 pounds sterling.
The qualities which will be considered in making a choice of scholars are: (1) Literary and scholastic
ability and attainments, (2) qualities of manhood, truth, courage, devotion to duty, sympathy, kindliness,
unselfishness and fellowship; (3)
exhibition of moral force of character and of instincts to lead and
to take an interest in his schoolmates; and (4) physical vigor as
shown by interest in outdoor sports
or in other ways.
The Hopkins men chosen will apPear with other applicants from
Maryland and the District of Columbia before the State Committee,
Which will nominate frpm the candidates applying to it the two best
men to appear before the District
Committee. The forty-eight states
have been divided into eight districts
of six states each. Each district
committee will select from the
twelve state-approved applicants,
four men to represent their states as
Rhode's Scholars at Oxford.
Further information and application blanks may be obtained from
Dean Berry.

Fifty white rats are subjects in a
psychology experiment which will
be conducted over a period of one
year under the direction of Dr. Roy
M. Dorcus, associate in psychology
of the Johns Hopkins University.
The experiments, which are being carried on in a temporary building behind Homewood Field, are
designed to ascertain if rats, given
the choice of foods both good and
bad for their physical well-being
will choose the food most beneficial
for them.
To make the selection more difficult, between the "staging box"
and the "feeding box" a maze is

IN

placed, so that the longest and mos'
difficult route is that leading to th(
best food, while food not so wel
suited for a rat's diet may be mosi
easily reached. Thus, the test wil
disclose also valuable informatior
as to the degrees of intelligence. T
C. E. Wilder, assistant to Dr. I ir
II
Dorcus, who is actually making the
tests and observations, explains that
since the tests have been under way
for so short a period conclusive re- SC(
sults have not been obtained, but
that it is believed much valuable information will be forthcoming over m
ac
the long period in which the studies
are being made.
